awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for US participation in four installments of the conference series "Midwest Partial Differential Equations Seminar" that will be held at University of Wisconsin, Madison in Spring 2018, University of Indiana, Bloomington in Fall 2018, Purdue University, West Lafayette in Spring 2019, and another midwestern university, to be determined, in Fall 2019.
 
The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the field of partial differential equations.   A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference series.  This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference.   The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities.   More information will be made available at:  http://homepages.math.uic.edu/~jlewis/midwpde/
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The brainchild of Avner Friedman who was then at Northwestern, Felix Browder at the University of Chicago, Mike Crandall at Wisconsin, and Salah Baouendi at Purdue, the Midwest Partial Differential Equations (MPDE) Seminars are approaching 45 years of activity. The concept was simple enough, convene a meeting on partial differential equations a couple of times a year in a rotating venue. This very same concept continues to be successful to this day, 

 

The NSF grant DMS-1800839 was originally aimed at covering several workshops between 2018 and 2020, and the first two meetings (83rd at Indiana University, Bloomington and 84th at Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago) successfully ran in Spring and Fall 2019. However, our plans for 2020 were completely upended by the start of the Coronavirus pandemic, and the associated lockdown. While other conferences switched to a virtual, online format during the lockdown, we decided that the in-person interactions that the MPDE Seminars foster are an integral part of the mission of our workshops. We therefore postponed our plans until we could resume in person meetings. The workshops indeed resumed in Spring 2022, and three highly successful meetings were held starting in Spring 2022: 85th MPDE Seminar at Baylor University, 86th at University of Missouri, Columbia, and 87th at Notre Dame University. 

 

Intellectual Merit. The Seminars provide rapid communication of problems, methods, and results and also enhance interactions among the researchers in the Midwest working in PDE and related fields. Strengthening these interactions, especially among junior researchers, was particularly important in the wake of the COVID lockdown, during which so much was done only virtually. The success of the meetings in 2022 and 2023 testify to the important role the MPDE Seminars continue to play in maintaining a diverse and active community of mathematicians interested in partial differential equations and their applications, and that was particularly 


Broader Impacts. Partial differential equations have numerous connections and applications in fields as diverse as geometry, analysis, mathematical physics, fluid dynamics, and mathematical biology. The Midwest PDE Seminar series bridges between these scientific areas over several generations, and brings together researchers from different age groups.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/02/2024
Modified by: Irina Nenciu
